h1.text: Job editor features

text: The job editor provides the following features for creating and editing jobs.
main_header: Job editor features

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using schema previews in the visual job editor

text: While creating or editing your job, you can use the Output schema tab to view the schema for your data.
main_header: Using schema previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using schema previews in the visual job editor

text: Before you can see the schema, the job editor needs permissions to access the data source. You can specify an IAM role on the Job details tab of the editor or on the Output schema tab for a node. If the IAM role has all the necessary permissions to access the data source, you can then view the schema on the Output schema tab for a node.
main_header: Using schema previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using data previews in the visual job editor

text: While creating or editing your job, you can use the Data preview tab to view a sample of your data.
main_header: Using data previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using data previews in the visual job editor

text: Before you can see the data sample, the job editor needs permissions to access the data source. The first time you choose the Data preview tab, you are prompted to choose an IAM role to use. This can be the same role that you plan to use for your job, or it can be a different role. The IAM role you choose must have the necessary permissions to create the data previews.
main_header: Using data previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using data previews in the visual job editor

text: After you choose an IAM role, it takes about 20 to 30 seconds before the data appears. You are charged for data preview usage as soon as you choose the IAM role. The following features help you when viewing the data.
main_header: Using data previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

h2.text: Using data previews in the visual job editor

text: Data previews help you create and test your job, without having to repeatedly run the job.
main_header: Using data previews in the visual job editor

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

text: When using data previews, you might encounter the following restrictions or limitations.
main_header: Restrictions when using data previews

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

text: When you use the visual editor to create a job, the ETL code is automatically generated for you. AWS Glue Studio creates a functional and complete job script, and saves it in an Amazon S3 location.
main_header: Script code generation

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

text: There are two forms of code generated by AWS Glue Studio: the original, or Classic version, and a newer, streamlined version. By default, the new code generator is used to create the job script. You can generate a job script using classic code generator on the Script tab by choosing the Generate classic script toggle button.
main_header: Script code generation

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

text: Some of the differences in the new version of the generated code include:
main_header: Script code generation

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Job editor features

text: New features in AWS Glue Studio require the new version of code generation, and will not work with the classic code script. You are prompted to update these jobs when you attempt to run them.
main_header: Script code generation

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Editing the data source node

text: To specify the data source properties, you first choose a data source node in the job diagram. Then, on the right side in the node details panel, you configure the node properties.
main_header: Editing the data source node

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using Data Catalog tables for the data source

text: For all data sources except Amazon S3 and connectors, a table must exist in the AWS Glue Data Catalog for the source type that you choose. AWS Glue Studio does not create the Data Catalog table.
main_header: Using Data Catalog tables for the data source

h1.text: Using a connector for the data source

text: If you select a connector for the Node type, follow the instructions at Authoring jobs with custom connectors to finish configuring the data source properties.
main_header: Using a connector for the data source

h1.text: Using files in Amazon S3 for the data source

text: If you choose Amazon S3 as your data source, then you can choose either:
main_header: Using files in Amazon S3 for the data source

h1.text: Using files in Amazon S3 for the data source

text: If you use an Amazon S3 bucket as your data source, AWS Glue Studio detects the schema of the data at the specified location from one of the files, or by using the file you specify as a sample file. Schema detection occurs when you use the Infer schema button. If you change the Amazon S3 location or the sample file, then you must choose Infer schema again to perform the schema detection using the new information.
main_header: Using files in Amazon S3 for the data source

h1.text: Using a streaming data source

text: You can create streaming extract, transform, and load (ETL) jobs that run continuously and consume data from streaming sources in Amazon Kinesis Data Streams, Apache Kafka, and Amazon Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (Amazon MSK).
main_header: Using a streaming data source

h1.text: Editing the data transform node

text: AWS Glue Studio provides a set of built-in transforms that you can use to process your data. Your data passes from one node in the job diagram to another in a data structure called a DynamicFrame, which is an extension to an Apache Spark SQL DataFrame.
main_header: Editing the data transform node

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Editing the data transform node

text: In the pre-populated diagram for a job, between the data source and data target nodes is the Transform - ApplyMapping node. You can configure this transform node to modify your data, or you can use additional transforms.
main_header: Editing the data transform node

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Editing the data transform node

text: The following built-in transforms are available with AWS Glue Studio:
main_header: Editing the data transform node

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using ApplyMapping to remap data property keys

text: An ApplyMapping transform remaps the source data property keys into the desired configured for the target data. In an ApplyMapping transform node, you can:
main_header: Using ApplyMapping to remap data property keys

h1.text: Using ApplyMapping to remap data property keys

text: You can add additional ApplyMapping nodes to the job diagram as needed â for example, to modify additional data sources or following a Join transform.
main_header: Using ApplyMapping to remap data property keys

h1.text: Using SelectFields to remove most data property keys

text: You can create a subset of data property keys from the dataset using the SelectFields transform. You indicate which data property keys you want to keep and the rest are removed from the dataset.
main_header: Using SelectFields to remove most data property keys

h1.text: Using DropFields to keep most data property keys

text: You can create a subset of data property keys from the dataset using the DropFields transform. You indicate which data property keys you want to remove from the dataset and the rest of the keys are retained.
main_header: Using DropFields to keep most data property keys

h1.text: Renaming a field in the dataset

text: You can use the RenameField transform to change the name for an individual property key in the dataset.
main_header: Renaming a field in the dataset

h1.text: Using Spigot to sample your dataset

text: To test the transformations performed by your job, you might want to get a sample of the data to check that the transformation works as intended. The Spigot transform writes a subset of records from the dataset to a JSON file in an Amazon S3 bucket. The data sampling method can be either a specific number of records from the beginning of the file or a probability factor used to pick records.
main_header: Using Spigot to sample your dataset

h1.text: Joining datasets

text: The Join transform allows you to combine two datasets into one. You specify the key names in the schema of each dataset to compare. The output DynamicFrame contains rows where keys meet the join condition. The rows in each dataset that meet the join condition are combined into a single row in the output DynamicFrame that contains all the columns found in either dataset.
main_header: Joining datasets

h1.text: Joining datasets

text: For an example of the join output schema, consider a join between two datasets with the following property keys:
main_header: Joining datasets

h1.text: Joining datasets

text: The join is configured to match on the id and hire_date keys using the = comparison operator.
main_header: Joining datasets

h1.text: Joining datasets

text: Because both datasets contain id and hire_date keys, you chose Resolve it to automatically add the prefix right to the keys in the right dataset.
main_header: Joining datasets

h1.text: Joining datasets

text: The keys in the output schema would be:
main_header: Joining datasets

h1.text: Using SplitFields to split a dataset into two

text: The SplitFields transform allows you to choose some of the data property keys in the input dataset and put them into one dataset and the unselected keys into a separate dataset. The output from this transform is a collection of DynamicFrames.
main_header: Using SplitFields to split a dataset into two

h1.text: Using SplitFields to split a dataset into two

text: The SplitFields transform is case sensitive. Add an ApplyMapping transform as a parent node if you need case-insensitive property key names.
main_header: Using SplitFields to split a dataset into two

h1.text: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

text: Certain transforms have multiple datasets as their output instead of a single dataset, for example, SplitFields. The SelectFromCollection transform selects one dataset (DynamicFrame) from a collection of datasets (an array of DynamicFrames). The output for the transform is the selected DynamicFrame.
main_header: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

h1.text: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

text: You must use this transform after you use a transform that creates a collection of DynamicFrames, such as:
main_header: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

h1.text: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

text: If you don't add a SelectFromCollection transform node to your job diagram after any of these transforms, you will get an error for your job.
main_header: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

h1.text: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

text: The parent node for this transform must be a node that returns a collection of DynamicFrames. If you choose a parent for this transform node that returns a single DynamicFrame, such as a Join transform, your job returns an error.
main_header: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

h1.text: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

text: Similarly, if you use a SelectFromCollection node in your job diagram as the parent for a transform that expects a single DynamicFrame as input, your job returns an error.
main_header: Overview of SelectFromCollection transform

h1.text: Using SelectFromCollection to choose which dataset to keep

text: Use the SelectFromCollection transform to convert a collection of DynamicFrames into a single DynamicFrame.
main_header: Using SelectFromCollection to choose which dataset to keep

h1.text: Find and fill missing values in a dataset

text: You can use the FillMissingValues transform to locate records in the dataset that have missing values and add a new field with a value determined by imputation. The input data set is used to train the machine learning (ML) model that determines what the missing value should be. If you use incremental data sets, then each incremental set is used as the training data for the ML model, so the results might not be as accurate.
main_header: Find and fill missing values in a dataset

h1.text: Filtering keys within a dataset

text: Use the Filter transform to create a new dataset by filtering records from the input dataset based on a regular expression. Rows that don't satisfy the filter condition are removed from the output.
main_header: Filtering keys within a dataset

h1.text: Filtering keys within a dataset

text: If you specify multiple filter conditions, the results are combined using an AND operator by default, but you can choose OR instead.
main_header: Filtering keys within a dataset

h1.text: Filtering keys within a dataset

text: The Filter transform is case sensitive. Add an ApplyMapping transform as a parent node if you need case-insensitive property key names.
main_header: Filtering keys within a dataset

h1.text: Using DropNullFields to remove fields with null values

text: Use the DropNullFields transform to remove fields from the dataset if all values in the field are ânullâ. By default, AWS Glue Studio will recognize null objects, but some values such as empty strings, strings that are ânullâ, -1 integers or other placeholders such as zeros, are not automatically recognized as nulls.
main_header: Using DropNullFields to remove fields with null values

h1.text: Using a SQL query to transform data

text: You can use a SQL transform to write your own transform in the form of a SQL query.
main_header: Using a SQL query to transform data

h1.text: Using a SQL query to transform data

text: A SQL transform node can have multiple datasets as inputs, but produces only a single dataset as output. In contains a text field, where you enter the Apache SparkSQL query. You can assign aliases to each dataset used as input, to help simply the SQL query. For more information about the SQL syntax, see the Spark SQL documentation.
main_header: Using a SQL query to transform data

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

text: If you need to perform more complicated transformations on your data, or want to add data property keys to the dataset, you can add a Custom code transform to your job diagram. The Custom code node allows you to enter a script that performs the transformation.
main_header: Creating a custom transformation

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

text: When using custom code, you must use a schema editor to indicate the changes made to the output through the custom code. When editing the schema, you can perform the following actions:
main_header: Creating a custom transformation

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

text: You must use a SelectFromCollection transform to choose a single DynamicFrame from the result of your Custom transform node before you can send the output to a target location.
main_header: Creating a custom transformation

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

text: Use the following tasks to add a custom transform node to your job diagram.
main_header: Creating a custom transformation

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

h2.text: Entering code for the custom transform node

text: You can type or copy code into an input field. The job uses this code to perform the data transformation. You can provide a code snippet in either Python or Scala. The code should take one or more DynamicFrames as input and returns a collection of DynamicFrames.
main_header: Entering code for the custom transform node

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

h2.text: Entering code for the custom transform node

text: The following examples show the format of the code to enter in the code box:
main_header: Entering code for the custom transform node

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

h2.text: Editing the schema in a custom transform node

text: When you use a custom transform node, AWS Glue Studio cannot automatically infer the output schemas created by the transform. You use the schema editor to describe the schema changes implemented by the custom transform code.
main_header: Editing the schema in a custom transform node

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

h2.text: Editing the schema in a custom transform node

text: A custom code node can have any number of parent nodes, each providing a DynamicFrame as input for your custom code. A custom code node returns a collection of DynamicFrames. Each DynamicFrame that is used as input has an associated schema. You must add a schema that describes each DynamicFrame returned by the custom code node.
main_header: Editing the schema in a custom transform node

h1.text: Creating a custom transformation

text: A custom code transform returns a collection of DynamicFrames, even if there is only one DynamicFrame in the result set.
main_header: Configure the custom transform output

h1.text: Configuring data target nodes

text: The data target is where the job writes the transformed data.
main_header: Configuring data target nodes

text: Your data target (also called a data sink) can be:
main_header: Overview of data target options

h1.text: Configuring data target nodes

text: You can choose to update the Data Catalog when your job writes to an Amazon S3 data target. Instead of requiring a crawler to update the Data Catalog when the schema or partitions change, this option makes it easy to keep your tables up to date. This option simplifies the process of making your data available for analytics by optionally adding new tables to the Data Catalog, updating table partitions, and updating the schema of your tables directly from the job.
main_header: Overview of data target options

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: The data target is where the job writes the transformed data.

h1.text: Editing or uploading a job script

text: Use the AWS Glue Studio visual editor to edit the job script or upload your own script.
main_header: Editing or uploading a job script

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Editing or uploading a job script

text: You can use the visual editor to edit job nodes only if the jobs were created with AWS Glue Studio. If the job was created using the AWS Glue console, through API commands, or with the command line interface (CLI), you can use the script editor in AWS Glue Studio to edit the job script, parameters, and schedule. You can also edit the script for a job created in AWS Glue Studio by converting the job to script-only mode.
main_header: Editing or uploading a job script

headers.title: Editing ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Editing or uploading a job script

h2.text: Creating and editing Scala scripts in AWS Glue Studio

text: When you choose the script editor for creating a job, by default, the job programming language is set to Python 3. If you choose to write a new script instead of uploading a script, AWS Glue Studio starts a new script with boilerplate text written in Python. If you want to write a Scala script instead, you must first configure the script editor to use Scala.

h1.text: Detect and process sensitive data

text: The Detect PII transform identifies Personal Identifiable Information (PII) in your data source. You choose the PII entity to identify, how you want the data to be scanned, and what to do with the PII entity that have been identified by the Detect PII transform.
main_header: Detect and process sensitive data

h1.text: Detect and process sensitive data

text: The Detect PII transform provides the ability to detect, mask, or remove entities that you define, or are pre-defined by AWS. This enables you to increase compliance and reduce liability. For example, you may want to ensure that no personally identifiable information exists in your data that can be read and want to mask social security numbers with a fixed strength (such as xxx-xx-xxxx), phone numbers, or addresses.
main_header: Detect and process sensitive data

h1.text: Detect and process sensitive data

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: AWS Glue provides an API that allows customers to create data integration jobs using the  AWS Glue API from a JSON object that represents a visual step workflow. Customers can then use the visual editor in AWS Glue Studio to work with these jobs.
main_header: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: For more information on Visual Job API data types, see Visual Job API.
main_header: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: The CreateJob and UpdateJob APIs now support an additional optional parameter, codeGenConfigurationNodes. Providing a non-empty JSON structure for this field will result in the DAG being registered in AWS Glue Studio for the created job and the associated code being generated. A null value or empty string for this field on job create will be ignored.
main_header: API design and CRUD APIs

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: Updates to the codeGenConfigurationNodes field will be done through the UpdateJob AWS Glue  API in a similar way as CreateJob. The entire field should be specified in UpdateJob where the DAG has been changed as desired. A null value provided will be ignored and no update to the DAG would be performed. An empty structure or string will cause the codeGenConfigurationNodes to be set as empty and any previous DAG removed. The GetJob API will return a DAG if one exists. The DeleteJob API will need to also delete any associated DAG.
main_header: API design and CRUD APIs

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: To create a job, use the CreateJob action (Python: create_job). The CreateJob request input will have an additional field âcodeGenConfigurationNodesâ where you can get specify the DAG object in JSON.
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: Things to keep in mind:
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: The following is a JSON representation of a CreateJob input.
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: Updating and getting obs
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: Since UpdateJob will also have a âcodeGenConfigurationNodesâ field, the input format will be the same. See UpdateJob Action (Python: update_job).
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: The GetJob action will return a âcodeGenConfigurationNodesâ field in the same format as well. See GetJob Action (Python: get_job).
main_header: Getting started

h1.text: AWS Glue Visual Job API (Preview)

text: Since the âcodeGenConfigurationNodesâ parameter has been added to existing APIs, any limitations in those APIs will be inherited. In addition, the codeGenConfigurationNodes and some nodes will be limited in size. See Job Structure for more information.
main_header: Visual job limitations

h1.text: Using Notebooks with AWS Glue Studio and AWS Glue

text: Data engineers can author AWS Glue jobs faster and more easily than before using the new interactive notebook interface in AWS Glue Studio or interactive sessions in AWS Glue.
main_header: Using Notebooks with AWS Glue Studio and AWS Glue

h1.text: Overview of using notebooks

text: AWS Glue Studio allows you to interactively author jobs in a notebook interface based on Jupyter Notebooks. Through notebooks in AWS Glue Studio, you can edit job scripts and view the output without having to run a full job, and you can edit data integration code and view the output without having to run a full job, and you can add markdown and save notebooks as .ipynb files and job scripts. You can start a notebook without installing software locally or managing servers. When you are satisified with your code, AWS Glue Studio can convert your notebook to a Glue job with the click of a button.
main_header: Overview of using notebooks

main_header: Overview of using notebooks

AWS Glue Studio configures a Jupyter notebook with the AWS Glue Jupyter kernel. You donât have to configure VPCs, network connections, or development endpoints to use this notebook.

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

text: AWS Glue provides built-in support for the most commonly used data stores (such as Amazon Redshift, Amazon Aurora, Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, MongoDB, and PostgreSQL) using JDBC connections. AWS Glue also allows you to use custom JDBC drivers in your extract, transform, and load (ETL) jobs. For data stores that are not natively supported, such as SaaS applications, you can use connectors.
main_header: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

text: A connector is an optional code package that assists with accessing data stores in AWS Glue Studio. You can subscribe to several connectors offered in AWS Marketplace.
main_header: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

text: When creating ETL jobs, you can use a natively supported data store, a connector from AWS Marketplace, or your own custom connectors. If you use a connector, you must first create a connection for the connector. A connection contains the properties that are required to connect to a particular data store. You use the connection with your data sources and data targets in the ETL job. Connectors and connections work together to facilitate access to the data stores.
main_header: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of using connectors and connections

text: A connection contains the properties that are required to connect to a particular data store. When you create a connection, it is stored in the AWS Glue Data Catalog. You choose a connector, and then create a connection based on that connector.
main_header: Overview of using connectors and connections

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of using connectors and connections

text: You can subscribe to connectors for non-natively supported data stores in AWS Marketplace, and then use those connectors when you're creating connections. Developers can also create their own connectors, and you can use them when creating connections.
main_header: Overview of using connectors and connections

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of using connectors and connections

text: The following steps describe the overall process of using connectors in AWS Glue Studio:
main_header: Overview of using connectors and connections

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: A connector is a piece of code that facilitates communication between your data store and AWS Glue. You can either subscribe to a connector offered in AWS Marketplace, or you can create your own custom connector.
main_header: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: AWS Glue Studio makes it easy to add connectors from AWS Marketplace.

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: You can also build your own connector and then upload the connector code to AWS Glue Studio.

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: Custom connectors are integrated into AWS Glue Studio through the AWS Glue Spark runtime API. The AWS Glue Spark runtime allows you to plug in any connector that is compliant with the Spark, Athena, or JDBC interface. It allows you to pass in any connection option that is available with the custom connector.
main_header: Creating custom connectors

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: You can encapsulate all your connection properties with AWS Glue Connections and supply the connection name to your ETL job. Integration with Data Catalog connections allows you to use the same connection properties across multiple calls in a single Spark application or across different applications.
main_header: Creating custom connectors

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Adding connectors to AWS Glue Studio

text: You can specify additional options for the connection. The job script that AWS Glue Studio generates contains a Datasource entry that uses the connection to plug in your connector with the specified connection options. For example:
main_header: Creating custom connectors

h1.text: Using connectors and connections with AWS Glue Studio

text: An AWS Glue connection is a Data Catalog object that stores connection information for a particular data store. Connections store login credentials, URI strings, virtual private cloud (VPC) information, and more. Creating connections in the Data Catalog saves the effort of having to specify all connection details every time you create a job.
main_header: Creating connections for connectors

text: If you delete a connector, this doesn't cancel the subscription for the connector in AWS Marketplace. To remove a subscription for a deleted connector, follow the instructions in Cancel a subscription for a connector .

h1.text: Tutorial: Using the open-source Elasticsearch Spark Connector

text: Elasticsearch is a popular open-source search and analytics engine for use cases such as log analytics, real-time application monitoring, and clickstream analysis. You can use OpenSearch as a data store for your extract, transform, and load (ETL) jobs by configuring the Elasticsearch Spark Connector in AWS Glue Studio. This connector is available for free from AWS Marketplace.
main_header: Tutorial: Using the open-source Elasticsearch Spark Connector

h1.text: Tutorial: Using the open-source Elasticsearch Spark Connector

text: In this tutorial, we will show how to connect to your Amazon OpenSearch Service nodes with a minimal number of steps.

text: When you create the AWS Glue ETL job, you specify an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role for the job to use. h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, availability, and performance of ETL jobs used in AWS Glue and AWS Glue Studio. You should collect monitoring data from all of the parts of your AWS solution so that you can more easily debug a multipoint failure if one occurs.
main_header: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: You access the job monitoring dashboard by choosing the Monitoring link in the AWS Glue Studio navigation pane.
main_header: Accessing the job monitoring dashboard

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

text: The job monitoring dashboard provides an overall summary of the job runs, with totals for the jobs with a status of Running, Canceled, Success, or Failed. Additional tiles provide the overall job run success rate, the estimated DPU usage for jobs, a breakdown of the job status counts by job type, worker type, and by day.
main_header: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

text: The graphs in the tiles are interactive. You can choose any block in a graph to run a filter that displays only those jobs in the Job runs table at the bottom of the page.
main_header: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

text: You can change the date range for the information displayed on this page by using the Date range selector. When you change the date range, the information tiles adjust to show the values for the specified number of days before the current date. You can also use a specific date range if you choose Custom from the date range selector.
main_header: Overview of the job monitoring dashboard

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: The Job runs resource list shows the jobs for the specified date range and filters.
main_header: Job runs view

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: You can filter the jobs on additional criteria, such as status, worker type, job type, and the job name. In the filter box at the top of the table, you can enter the text to use as a filter. The table results are updated with rows that contain matching text as you enter the text.
main_header: Job runs view

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

text: You can view a subset of the jobs by choosing elements from the graphs on the job monitoring dashboard. For example, if you choose the number of running jobs in the Job runs summary tile, then the Job runs list displays only the jobs that currently have a status of Running. If you choose one of the bars in the Worker type breakdown bar chart, then only job runs with the matching worker type and status are shown in the Job runs list.
main_header: Job runs view

h2.text: Viewing Amazon CloudWatch metrics for a job run

text: On the details page for a job run, below the Run details section, you can view the job metrics. AWS Glue Studio sends job metrics to Amazon CloudWatch for every job run.
main_header: Viewing Amazon CloudWatch metrics for a job run

h1.text: Monitoring ETL jobs in AWS Glue Studio

h2.text: Viewing Amazon CloudWatch metrics for a job run

text: AWS Glue reports metrics to Amazon CloudWatch every 30 seconds. The AWS Glue metrics represent delta values from the previously reported values. Where appropriate, metrics dashboards aggregate (sum) the 30-second values to obtain a value for the entire last minute. However, the Apache Spark metrics that AWS Glue passes on to Amazon CloudWatch are generally absolute values that represent the current state at the time they are reported.
main_header: Viewing Amazon CloudWatch metrics for a job run

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

text: You can use the simple graphical interface in AWS Glue Studio to manage your ETL jobs. Using the navigation menu, choose Jobs to view the Jobs page. On this page, you can see all the jobs that you have created either with AWS Glue Studio or the AWS Glue console. You can view, manage, and run your jobs on this page.
main_header: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

text: In AWS Glue Studio, you can run your jobs on demand. A job can run multiple times, and each time you run the job, AWS Glue collects information about the job activities and performance. This information is referred to as a job run and is identified by a job run ID.
main_header: Start a job run

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

text: You can initiate a job run in  the following ways in AWS Glue Studio:
main_header: Start a job run

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

links.title: Working with Jobs on the AWS Glue Console

text: For more information about job runs, see Working with Jobs on the AWS Glue Console in the AWS Glue Developer Guide.
main_header: Start a job run

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

text: In AWS Glue Studio, you can create a schedule to have your jobs run at specific times. You can specify constraints, such as the number of times that the jobs run, which days of the week they run, and at what time. These constraints are based on cron and have the same limitations as cron. For example, if you choose to run your job on day 31 of each month, keep in mind that some months don't have 31 days. For more information about cron, see Cron Expressions in the AWS Glue Developer Guide.
main_header: Schedule job runs

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

text: After you have created schedules for a job, you can open the job in the visual editor and choose the Schedules tab to manage the schedules.
main_header: Manage job schedules

text: The nodes in the job diagram define the actions performed by the job, but there are several properties that you can configure for the job as well. These properties determine the environment that the job runs in, the resources it uses, the threshold settings, the security settings, and more.
main_header: Modify the job properties

h1.text: Managing ETL jobs with AWS Glue Studio

h3.text: Store Spark shuffle files on Amazon S3

text: Some ETL jobs require reading and combining information from multiple partitions, for example, when using a join transform. This operation is referred to as shuffling. During a shuffle, data is written to disk and transferred across the network. With AWS Glue version 3.0, you can configure Amazon S3 as a storage location for these files. AWS Glue provides a shuffle manager which writes and reads shuffle files to and from Amazon S3. Writing and reading shuffle files from Amazon S3 is slower (by 5%-20%) compared to local disk (or Amazon EBS which is heavily optimized for Amazon EC2). However, Amazon S3 provides unlimited storage capacity, so you don't have to worry about "No space left on device" errors when running your job.
main_header: Store Spark shuffle files on Amazon S3

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

text: For this AWS Glue scenario, you're asked to analyze arrival data for major air carriers to calculate the popularity of departure airports month over month. You have flights data for the year 2016 in CSV format stored in Amazon S3. Before you transform and analyze your data, you catalog its metadata in the AWS Glue Data Catalog.
main_header: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

text: In this tutorial, letâs add a crawler that infers metadata from these flight logs in Amazon S3 and creates a table in your Data Catalog.
main_header: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

text: This tutorial assumes that you have an AWS account and access to AWS Glue.
main_header: Prerequisites

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

text: Use these steps to configure and run a crawler that extracts the metadata from a CSV file stored in Amazon S3.
main_header: Step 1: Add a crawler

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

text: After creating a crawler, the wizard sends you to the Crawlers view page. Because you create the crawler with an on-demand schedule, you're given the option to run the crawler.
main_header: Step 2: Run the crawler

h1.text: Tutorial: Adding an AWS Glue crawler

h2.text: Step 3: View AWS Glue Data Catalog objects

text: The crawler reads data at the source location and creates tables in the Data Catalog. A table is the metadata definition that represents your data, including its schema. The tables in the Data Catalog do not contain data. Instead, you use these tables as a source or target in a job definition.
main_header: Step 3: View AWS Glue Data Catalog objects
